channel.title: Comments on: 3525 South Bronson Ave.
channel.description: Blogging demolitions one building at a time.

item.title: By: Thelma Mericle
item.dc:creator: Thelma Mericle
item.description: Such a beautiful diamond in the rough. C'mon someone - step up to the plate and make this ol' girl beautiful again! Does anyone know anyone who may be interested? Ask around. Let's don't let her disappear!

item.title: By: Nathan Marsak
item.dc:creator: Nathan Marsak
item.description:
In reply to <a href="https://www.riplosangeles.com/3525-south-bronson-ave/#comment-62">Paul Wright</a>.
Hey Paul——well I agree with everything you say, except for the final sentence (as you might imagine). The house needs a lot of love, but it's not so far gone that it can't be brought back. Maybe it's not a great block, or the best neighborhood for old houses (though there's some nifty old houses still on 12th, and Edgehill, even a couple on Norton) but I'd say that's exactly the <em>point</em> of our needing to retain this one; it's like the last of its kind in the area. A lot of people replying to the Instagram post were all "oh no! I know that house—I drive by it all the time and always notice it" because it's something of a landmark in those parts. If it vanishes then kids will grow up thinking the area was "born" into hacked n' whacked, without a touchstone of how it once was.

item.title: By: Paul Wright
item.dc:creator: Paul Wright
item.description: I went to the house on Bronson on Sunday to check it out. It's a complete mess on an odd lot next to a giant mega church. Plus every building on that block is some 1 story muli-family dwelling. What's tragic to me is what the neighborhood has gone through. Butchered, hacked and whacked into this odd mess. As much as I love history and saving the old, this is the first time I am ever agreeing to just tear this down.
